```{r setup, include=FALSE}
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE)
knitr::opts_knit$set(root.dir = "/Users/Addie/Intro to Data Science/FinalProject/data")
library(tidyverse)
```

When you click the **Knit** button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. You can embed an R code chunk like this:

```{r dataframe setup}
communities <- read_csv("communities.data")
communities <- transform(communities,
                         state = as.integer(state),
                         county = as.integer(county),
                         community = as.integer(county),
                         communityname = as.factor(communityname),
                         fold = as.integer(fold),
                         racePctBlack = as.integer(racepctblack),
                         numbUrban = as.integer(numbUrban),
                         pctUrban = as.integer(pctUrban),
                         NumIlleg = as.integer(NumIlleg),
                         MedOwnCostPctIncNoMtg = as.integer(MedOwnCostPctIncNoMtg),
                         NumInShelters = as.integer(NumInShelters),
                         NumStreet = as.integer(NumStreet),
                         LemasSwFTPerPop = as.integer(LemasSwFTPerPop),
                         PolicPerPop = as.integer(PolicPerPop),
                         LemasGangUnitDeploy = as.integer(LemasGangUnitDeploy),
                         PolicBudgPerPop = as.integer(PolicBudgPerPop))
communities <- relocate(communities, racePctBlack, .before = racePctWhite)
communities <- subset(communities, select = -(racepctblack))
communities
```

```{r, echo = FALSE}
plot()
```

Note that the `echo = FALSE` parameter was added to the code chunk to prevent printing of the R code that generated the plot.
